subject: Self Care
title: Impulse Control
description: A micro-lesson that makes Impulse Control usable.

hook.text: The famous marshmallow test showed kids who waited for two marshmallows outperformed impulsive kids for decades.

buildup.text: Walter Mischel discovered that delayed gratification predicted academic success, health, and income years later.

discovery.text: Successful kids didn't just resist. They used strategies â€” looking away, singing, reframing the marshmallow mentally.

twist.text: Impulse control isn't about suffering through urges. It's about redirecting attention so the urge weakens naturally.

climax.text: When tempted, shift focus. Distract, reframe, or delay by ten minutes. Most impulses fade if you outlast them.

punchline.text: Don't fight the urge. Outlast it. It fades on its own.

quiz.question: What strategy did successful kids use in the marshmallow test?
options: They redirected attention by looking away or reframing
They were naturally patient without any strategy
